content: The "Juvenile Justice Reform Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. It includes definitions for key terms. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include new definitions, such as the term 'contact' and 'juvenile justice stakeholders'. These definitions encompass interactions between juveniles and adults in custody, as well as individuals and agencies involved in the juvenile justice system. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include new definitions for 'juvenile justice stakeholders', which involve youth and families of color, defense attorneys, prosecutors, judges, school systems, law enforcement, juvenile detention, probation departments, and community-based providers. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include reporting requirements on how State plans are meeting specific criteria. Section 223(a) of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include individuals with special experience in addressing the needs of girls or implementing gender responsive services. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include a plan for providing accessible, community-based services to at-risk youth. This includes individuals with special experience in addressing the needs of girls or implementing gender responsive services. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for juveniles charged with violations of court orders or held under the Interstate Compact on Juveniles. Efforts will be made to safely care for these juveniles using staff-secure and community-based resources within 3 years of the effective date. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for juveniles awaiting trial or legal process and treated as adults for prosecution. Efforts will be made to utilize staff-secure and community-based alternatives for their care within 3 years. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to ensure that juveniles treated as adults for prosecution in criminal court are not held in adult jails or lockups while awaiting trial. Additionally, the bill includes provisions to address race and ethnicity in the juvenile justice system. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address racial and ethnic disparities among youth in the juvenile justice system by implementing improvement strategies at various levels. This includes establishing coordinating bodies composed of stakeholders to oversee efforts to reduce disparities. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address racial and ethnic disparities among youth in the juvenile justice system. This involves community leaders and service providers identifying key decision points that create disparities and developing data collection systems to pinpoint where these disparities exist. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address disparities in the juvenile justice system by tracking and analyzing data disaggregated by factors such as race, ethnicity, sex, geography, offense, delinquency history, and age. This includes developing a work plan with measurable objectives to reduce bias and differential treatment of youth of color. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address disparities in the juvenile justice system by tracking and publicly reporting efforts and progress made in reducing bias and differential treatment of youth of color. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address disparities in the juvenile justice system by tracking and publicly reporting efforts and progress made in reducing bias and differential treatment of youth of color. Research and evaluation are emphasized in Section 5. Section 251 of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include treating juveniles as adults for prosecution in criminal court. The Administrator is required to assess the effectiveness of this practice within 3 years and report on it within 6 months. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include treating juveniles as adults for prosecution in criminal court. Within 3 years, the Administrator must assess the effectiveness of this practice and submit a report with findings, conclusions, and recommended changes in law within 6 months. The report must be made available to the public. SEC. 6. Incentive grants for local delinquency prevention programs are amended to include gender-specific services. SEC. 7. The Act and its amendments will take effect in the 1st fiscal year after enactment.
